block.p: RUSSIA: AMERICAN'S PLEA SCHEDULED -- A day after Edmond Pope's wife and his congressman made a public appeal for better medical treatment for the former naval intelligence officer awaiting trial in Moscow on espionage charges, a Moscow court scheduled a hearing to reconsider his plea for conditional release. The Moscow City Court announced it will hear an appeal Sept. 11 from Mr. Pope's lawyer, Pavel Astakhov, whose earlier filings were rejected.

CROATIA: TRIBUNAL WITNESS SLAIN -- A Croatian witness in war crimes trials who testified nearly two years ago was slain in a bomb blast near his home in Zagreb in what was seen as a warning to others who might testify to the International Criminal Tribunal on the Former Yugoslavia about possible Croatian war crimes in Bosnia. Tribunal officials said Milan Levar was given government protection in April 1998, and that they had had no contact with him since.

NORTHERN IRELAND: HUME GIVES UP A SEAT -- John Hume, the leader of the moderate Catholic Social Democratic and Labor Party and a principal architect of the Ulster peace pact, said he was giving up his seat in the new Northern Ireland Assembly, cutting his workload for health reasons. Mr. Hume, 63, will keep his party post and his seats in the British Parliament and the European Parliament.

NORTHERN IRELAND: TRIMBLE SPEAKS OUT -- The British province's most powerful Protestant politician, the Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble, condemned warring Protestant paramilitary groups whose turf war led to the firebombing of more than 25 homes in two towns and has resulted in the deaths of three men and the shooting of an 11-year-old girl in the past 10 days. The police say the violence is a struggle for control of the drug trade.

BRITAIN: STRIKE HITS TOURISTS -- Thousands of vacationing British tourists were stranded at ferry terminals on both sides of the English Channel as French fishermen blockaded piers to protest rising fuel prices. Also on the rise were neighborly irritations. One Englishman stuck in Calais, David Langford, 28, of King's Lynn, Norfolk, said, ''I've just traveled from Thailand and I have come through 11 countries, and it is always France that causes the trouble.''

WEST TIMOR: U.N. RESUMES AID -- The United Nations has resumed aid to East Timor refugees in camps in West Timor after Indonesia arrested two suspects in the beating of three aid workers on Aug. 23. Authorities in West Timor, which shares an island with East Timor and is moving to independence under United Nations administration, also opened an inquiry into violence against aid workers.

MYANMAR: PLEA ON ACTIVIST -- International pressure mounted on the military government as the pro-democracy activist Daw Aung San Suu Kyi entered the seventh day of a roadside confrontation with the authorities. Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations called on the ruling generals to resolve the standoff with Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, who is camped with a group of followers just outside the capital after a symbolic attempt to travel to meet with supporters.

IRAN: REFORMERS' RESTRAINT -- Mainstream reformers scrambled to head off rising anger on campuses after five days of Islamic vigilante violence against the student movement. Reformist legislators from the Islamic Iran Participation Front denounced attacks by hard-line gangs, backed by elements of the security forces, on a student gathering in Khorramabad, but warned students not to take to the streets.

MEXICO: BANKER LOSES A ROUND -- A banker who fled Mexico after being charged with $700 million in fraud in 1994 has lost another round in his fight to avoid extradition from Australia. An Australian federal judge rejected an appeal of an extradition order by Carlos Cabal Peniche, left, the Mexican attorney general reported. Also affected is Mr. Cabal's brother-in-law, Marco Pasini. They can now appeal to the full three-judge federal court.

SIERRA LEONE: FIVE SOLDIERS FREED -- A British military spokesman said that five British soldiers were released by their captors and were safe and well in the capital, Freetown. In London, a Foreign Office spokesman said negotiations would resume early today for the release of the remaining six British soldiers held in the jungle by a renegade group called the West Side Boys.

ZIMBABWE: COST OF WAR -- The new minister of finance disclosed to Parliament that the country's two-year-long involvement in Congo's civil war has cost about $200 million, nearly three times more than previously disclosed. Even as its own economy has crumbled over the last two years, Zimbabwe has had thousands of troops stationed in Congo battling rebels backed by Rwanda and Uganda.

SOUTH AFRICA: PLEA ON RACISM -- Opening a national conference on racism, President Thabo Mbeki urged South Africans to fight the scourge that continues to afflict the nation six years after the end of apartheid. He acknowledged that some whites may consider the topic divisive, but he said the struggle will fail unless people work together.

MOZAMBIQUE: ELECTION REPORT -- In its final report on Mozambique's elections, the Carter Center found that the credibility of the vote was marred by technical problems and a lack of transparency in the final count. But the center officials, who observed the elections on Dec. 3, 4 and 5, said the problems did not affect the result. President Joaquim Chissano was re-elected and his party retained control.
